title: Lulz Mini Rounded Spool Arm
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a rework of the original Lulzbot Mini spool arm. All I did was take the original design and add a smooth rounded nose for the spool to sit on. I also tweaked the stops on either end since my mod added some height. Quick and easy if you don't want to go with a spindle or an alternate mounting system. You could also wrap the now-rounded edge in some teflon tape to make it silky smooth.

You don't need any supports...the curve is small enough to eliminate that hassle.

LulzBot

title: Meat Stomper for LEM meat grinder

description.text:
My older LEM #5 meat grinder needed a new stomper. The ones I'm finding at the store are all for the bigger bore Big Bites and won't fit. So I made my own.

Two parts to minimize supports. Glue them together. Short enough to avoid hitting the auger (which is what messed up my original one!)

title: SW Commander Wolf
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
One of many Helmets I'd like to print and add to the collection. The files I've included here consist of the 3 stages I worked on from the original file through to thickening the helmet and then a basic smoothing modifier. I'm still in the early stages of leaning about retaining sharp edges on a model and I'm still struggling to get my head round it ; ) If you find you like these files as is all good. if you have the skills to improve on the model further please do and reupload as a remix so we can all enjoy, Cheers Jace

I'll come back and do my best to improve on these files as I develope my skill level ; )

author: asuper21

description.text:
This is a complete overhaul of a different idea. I saw the Batman design in a much larger version and it was for headphones. This is a simple clip I use for the deck of role cards we use for playing Magic the gathering EDH - Kingdoms. If you're unfamiliar with this mode of EDH, look into it, I won't explain it here.

I realized I could just make the clip press fit into the hand model via the pin cutout, and now I have a nice little package to keep everything together.

The Necromancer's Bells, inspired by Garth Nix's Old Kingdom series.

The bells were designed by concept artist Josh Wong as part of a project that reimagined people, places, and objects from the first book in Garth Nix's Old Kingdom series, Sabriel.

You can see the rest of Josh's illustrations on his portfolio page.

Prop fabrication and printing were done by Jeanette Denham of Xmachina Cosplay.

3D design was done by Eric Lange.

  • The Necromancer's Bells print with minimum support, only a little under the actual bell itself.
  • Some support removal is necessary for bell 6 between the top surface and the claws.
  • Bell 7 is slightly over 10 inches (254 mm) tall.
  • All bells can be scaled down slightly without losing too much detail.

If you make these, feel free to share pictures and let us know at @xmachniacosplay, @joshwongart, and @30secfantasy!

Photography on this Thing is copyright Eric Lange 2017.
Necromancer's Bells illustration is copyright Josh Wong 2017.
The 3D data is under a Creative Commons - Attribution license.

description.text:
This is a simple Thing. I needed a way to hold some cuttings from my Nepenthes Ventrata (carnivorous pitcher plants) so I could get them to root and grow into new (clone) plants. I just did a quick design to be basic and fill that need.

The .stl file is one half of the holder. You print two of them for each cutting you want to root and then put them together inside the ring of a standard canning jar. Put the ring onto the jar with the "bottom" of the cutting pointed down into the jar, fill the jar with water and wait. If you are lucky, the cutting will put out roots and you have a new clone of your favorite plant, ready to be potted.

This will work for other types of plants as well, just so long as the stems are not more than 5mm or 0.19685 in. in diameter. Of course, feel free to modify this thing if you need another size.

P.S. The picture of the plant in the white hanging pot was included to sate any curiosity about what kind of plant this crazy person was talking about.

To get a better grip on my different filaments and their print behaviour, I created a quick and simple model that contains some curves, angles and flats. Nothing special.

I also numbered them for better identification and put my print settings in a spreadsheet.

I then took each one and printed them with different settings.
i.e. A-1: 0.4mm height, A-2: 0.2mm height, A-3: 0.1mm height.

title: Redesigned E3D V6 Mount for HyperCube w/ Dual 5015 Fans and BLTouch Mount

description.text:
So I wasn't super happy with the overhang results of the OG HyperCube so I redesigned the entire E3D V6 mount and clamp system.

This new mount allows you to install 2x 5015 blower fans on either side of the hotend for much better cooling performance. I included some pics of some overhang tests. One test maxes out at 75° the other at 80° with some text on the end. Both turned out quite nicely.

This system also places the BLTouch directly behind the hotend for access to more of the printbed. In my case, I can probe my entire bed with my BLTouch now.

NOTE: The probe offset for this mount is X=0 Y=21.2

You will need some M3 machine screws and nuts to fasten everything. It should be pretty self explanatory. I recommend using small washers for fastening the blower fans.

Printer:

HyperCube

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

60%

Notes:

I printed everything in PETG at 60% infill (full honeycomb). I personally print my PETG at 250C with these fans at about 60% and the parts turn out incredibly strong.

You will need to print the fan duct twice if you are using two blower fans.

I have attached a screenshot of how everything should be printed.

Turn supports off as there are built in supports for the clamp and no other part needs them.

The fan ducts are meant to be a tight fit so you may have to file or trim the area that fits into the blower fans. Don't take away too much material as you still want the fit to be fairly tight. I have had no issues with them popping out mid print.

remixed_from.title: 2 Liter Bottle Holder with Funnel and Cap

title: Miniature Holder for Painting Miniatures (2 versions)

description.text:
This is a stand to hold miniatures while painting. There are two versions: one is designed to mount on top of a wooden spool from Hobby Lobby (or other suitable block). The other is designed to screw onto the top of a standard 500ml bottle (I believe 2 liter bottles will work as well). I remixed the bottle neck and bottle cap portions from other Thingiverse models (see Remix Section for details).

The basic parts go together without glue, and the bar is designed such that the collar and bar will rotate around the base as needed to help steady your hand.

If you want to use bottle caps to hold the model, there is an optional bottle neck model (which DOES require gluing) which can be placed on top of the base. Miniatures can then be placed on bottle caps and screwed into place for painting, then removed (and another model added) while the paint dries. This allows the painter to have multiple models under paint, with only one painting stand needed.

Assembly

Clean the parts, then gently spread the collar until it slides over the rim of the base. Spin it back and forth a few times until motion is easy and the tabs on the collar come together.

Choose a bar (the Tall Bar will work for man-sized minis). Insert the bar, hole-end first, between the two tabs of the collar and insure it seats tightly in the space.

Take one of the small locking pins, and insert it into the square hole with the flat side of the locking pin towards the collar ring. Insert the other locking pin from the other side. Squeeze the locking pins into the collar until the rims of the locking pins are against the collar tabs.

If you need to swap out the bar for a different one, the locking pins can be eased out and the bar removed/replaced.

If you use the bottle version, I recommend filling the bottle with water, sand, or other ballast to make it rock steady of the workbench.

This is a replacement for the plastic parts of the print head for the 3D Systems Cube 3.
Used for modifying the feed system.

See instructions here:
http://www.print3dforum.com/showthread.php/1075-(BETA)-Cube3-Printable-Nozzle-Replacement-by-MegaloDon?p=42476&viewfull=1#post42476

More mods for the Cube 3 can be found here:
http://www.print3dforum.com/forumdisplay.php/31-Cube3

The Borromean rings consist of three rings with the property that no two of the rings are linked, even though all three rings together cannot come apart. Print all together or a ring at a time with assembly while the third ring is printing. The hexagonal model can print in one piece with no support or raft! For more mathematical information and to see OpenSCAD code for each model, see these MakerHome links:

description.text:
A modified dice tray from my former vanilla design at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2490052

Graphics on this dice tray are derived from Template Pack #16 Vikings by Lord Zsezse Works(c) – 2011-2015 http://www.lordzsezseworks.com/ and are used with permission of Lord ZseZse Works under their licence.

http://www.drivethrurpg.com/product/146440/Template-Pack-16-Vikings?manufacturers_id=3154

You have the permission to change, resize, re-coloring or cut the designs in any way you would like but you cannot sell this product as a template pack again with any changes or contrary to the spirit of the attached licence.

Done up in a nice ply or wood and not MDF or HDF, then stained or laquered, I'm certain this would make a fetching gift for family, friends or yourself. Test copy cut on MDF pictured above.

Formatted for cutting on the top half of 6mm MDF cut to (Arch C) 24" x 18" sized sheet, which fits across the bed of an Epilog Helix. Duplicate the graphics to fill the sheet or rotate the sheet 180 degrees to cut another tray. All my patterns are designed for cutting at 300dpi. I have provided the PDF and SVG files that I converted online at https://cloudconvert.com/vsd-to-svg. Designed with Visio and PhotoShop. Shared as is.

If you are inclined to be more than a taker and a consumer, pay forward by contributing to this site, as so many others have before you, or perform a random act of kindness, or donate to a good cause when the opportunity next arises. If you liked it enough to download it I'd appreciate a LIKE, it helps get the word out and spread these designs around. That is all.

Now go out and repel those Viking Hoardes!

description.text: Drone motor presser for 8mm brush motors

First off, let me please ask that if you like these designs and find them useful please do like, follow and share my content. And if you have any ideas or concepts to modify the content I would love to hear!

The feet on my Mid 2012 MacBook Pro finally all broke off. Dust was entering through the holes, the bottom was scratching and I just didn't like what was going on. So I designed these feet which can be glued (I use epoxy) to the original location of the feet. They protrude a small amount to elevate the laptop body. I work quite a bit with intensive graphics and computational tasks and the added height helps with heat dissipation from the bottom cover.

To install these I unscrew the bottom cover and glue them into their locations. This avoids any stray glue from entering into the body and attaching itself to somewhere you didn't wish it too. It is also a great opportunity to blow out all those ants, dust and food crumbs.

The glue I used for mounting them was Araldites 5 minute epoxy.

print_settings.Notes:: I print these with support with the hooks sideways so the layers are perpendicular to the pegboard for added strength and an easier fit.

description.text:
This is an OpenSCAD library to make pegboard bases so you can hang your things on your pegboard. I saw several hooks and bases floating around, but none were parametric to make it work with what you have at home.

To use it in your own designs, it's just:

use <Parametric Pegboard Base.scad>;
pegboard_base(cols, rows, hole_center_to_center, peg_height, base_depth, hole_size, peg_clearance, top_peg_angle);

I've tried to set everything up with sane defaults as well.

The included STLs are just examples of what you can make.

The 5x5 is:

pegboard_base(5, 5);

The 2x4 is:

pegboard_base(2, 4);

The 3x2 is:

pegboard_base(3, 2, angle = 90)

The 3x5 in:

pegboard_base(3, 5, height = .25 * 25.4)

Unfortunately, due to some quirks around Thingiverse's handling of rotate_extrude(), this design doesn't work with Customizer. This is also why the top pegs on the SCAD thumbnail don't render right. It all works correctly actually in OpenSCAD.

Printer:

BIQU Kossel Plus

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

N/A: All perimeters

Notes:

I print these with support with the hooks sideways so the layers are perpendicular to the pegboard for added strength and an easier fit.
If you print the same orientation I do, you have to do a little cleanup after removing the support material so the pegs fit in the holes, but it's not too bad.

print_settings.Notes:: Print settings are fairly unimportant, so long as your machine makes accurate parts.  I needed only a very light sanding on the taps for the braces, and otherwise everything snapped together nicely.  No glue needed.

description.text:
I like the concept, but noticed issues. A lot of these design ideas are great, but fail to properly fit the items.
I decided to fix this. I have printed it and tested it and know if works PERFECTLY (I am just too lazy to deal with pictures :) )
The tip has been extended so it grabs the cube properly and is firm so if someone picks it up, nothing is going to fly.
I also changed the bottom grip slide that goes into the base so it fits better. I had to file the first one down just to get it to fit well. Perfect dimensions for the opening, but this is 3d printing and you need some spacing when fiting pieces.
So it worked great and hope people can use it. The base needed no changing and liked it. I thought about adding some layers so it looked more like a pedestal, but went against the concept.

description.text:
This is the result of a bunch of begleri Discord guys ideas coming together in the "best" possible way. Really gives a new meaning to juggling.

Two editions are here for the folks that print in something other than ABS/PLA, The recessed version is great for printing brass/steel for heavier weight.

The hex nut version is for PLA/ABS and use of a hex nut (1/4'')

There are two additional rings, one for printing in heavier weight, and a second larger ring as an additional set. The second larger ring will also accept a hex nut for weight.

Edit: Now contains a compatible inner hardcore and outer hardcore version to use with AO2 sets!

description.text:
My kid loves things that spin and refrigerator magnets. So when I saw her play with the gear magnet toys at the museum I knew we had to have some.

It is simply a set of customizable gears that you can press a 608 bearing and magnet into. The magnet was selected because it is the perfect size to press into the bearing, though I do recommend using a dab of glue to keep it permanent because tolerances can make some looser than others.

The gears also have 4 optional locating pins that allow you to stack them to make a gear train! (FYI Doing this makes them hurt to step on!)

Get your bearings here: http://amzn.to/2ziLeex
Get your magnets here: http://amzn.to/2yJhsTn

Also note that I lowered the pressure angle in the model from what I used to help reduce the gear separation forces. My gears range from 15 to 25 teeth but the magnets are strong enough that you could do more.

Video Link:
https://youtu.be/Kw-B28VF0A4

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.3 or finer

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Printed in ABS and PLA successfully. I liked ABS better because I didn't end up with lots of sharp edges this being a kids toy and all. I made one using flexible filament and it was a total failure and I don't recommend it.

3 perimeters all sides minimum. Supports are recommended for the section where the bearing presses in.

comments.text:
I noticed you used ABS. We only have access to PLA. Do you think these will hold up in PLA? This is all pretty new to me.
Thanks!
comments.author: MechEngineerMike

comments.text:
PLA is usually my preferred material but in this case I recommended ABS for a couple reasons.
In PLA you will have to watch out for sharp edges since these will be handled by kids. Also, the 4 pins on top will be more likely to snap off so I would recommend opening up the thingiverse customizer and turning off the 4 pins. (or just print them as is and intentionally break off all the pins so it doesn't happen later.)
Also on another note, I would recommend finishing off the assembled toys with a dab of superglue or epoxy to help keep the magnets inside just in case.
comments.author: lkeener

comments.text: There is a slight variance in the feel of the press fit between the magnets & bearings & some did fall out prior to gluing them in. I would definitely recommend epoxying each one.

title: Poly Die Case with TPU liner

description.text:
This is a simple poly die set case with 7 compartments (D20, D12, D10decimal, D10, D8, D6, D4). TPU cups are held in place with friction and replace the traditional felt usually found in a die case. This fits the standard die size (something like Chessex) and was enlarged to handle the slightly larger die set from Metalic Dice Games. (https://shop.metallicdicegames.com/)

Use 15x6x3 Rare Earth magnets like (https://www.aliexpress.com/item/10pcs-15-x-6-x-3mm-N35-Super-Strong-Magnet-Block-NdFeB-Cuboid-Rare-Earth-Neodymium/32464731037.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.zCxR9L)

It seems to work staying closed when dropped from low heights, I don't think it works for heights above a few feet, substituting larger magnets might help there.

author: Carcin

description.text: This is a replica of K's blaster from the movie Blade Runner 2049. It's modeled using a video reference and no measurements. It's reasonably accurate and incredibly imprecise.

Modeled using Tested's video of Adam Savage examining the new Blade Runner blasters:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FqdsYn9TdWQ

Also referenced was this photo:
http://www.figures.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/DSCN8700.jpg

Due to not having the real blaster on hand, I made the overall size the same as Deckard's original blaster (about 10 inches).

This model is by no means perfect, in fact it is likely that not a single piece of the model lines up exactly with the original, however overall it does serve as a convincing costume piece.

There are many things that could be tweaked to be more accurate, I have included the original SolidWorks file if you wish to tweak those yourself.

description.text: Fill the flask up tipping a little bit to the one side so the water goes down the larger tube. Then when you go to pour out of that same side it will look like you dumped out all the water. Right the flask, and then when you pour again, more water will come out. You can repeat it several times before the reservoir is empty. I've seen similar at magic shops, but they require you plug a hole, this does not require any special hand placement. Only that you pour the correct way so you don't get water in the thinner u-tube meant to equalize the air pressure. Video: http://youtu.be/unbIjZYowtg

When you print it, the top of the bottom reservoir gets a little goofed up, but it straightens itself out.  I printed it with 10% fill and it works just fine.  I'm sure it could have been designed better, but it is functional.

comments.text: I think this is really cool because with this design you could even have it handed out to the audience and ask them to pour out some water.

description.text:
This is my 3D printer I've built as my matriculation project in the fall of 2016. My goal was to design and build my own 3D printer. Furthermore I wanted to use as many 3D printed parts as possible because I was intrigued by the thought of 3D printing a 3D printer. I don't have a full tutorial but I'll try to give you some information about the printer.

I used 40x40mm aluminium extrusion for the main structure and 20x20mm aluminium extrusion for the bed structure. Overall the printer has turned out to be extremely robust and reliable. These were also my intentions since I wanted the structure to be as rigid as possible so I wouldn't run into problems with the frame twisting and the axes being misaligned.

I used 123D Design for all of the CAD work and I'd be happy to provide the original files if anyone chooses to build this printer. I printed all 3D printed parts with Velleman PLA on my Vertex k8400. The PLA parts have held up really well, to my surprise, so I didn't feel like I need to reprint them in ABS. In total it had taken me about 130 hours to print all parts (excluding prototypes).

The electronics are based on a Arduino Uno with a Ramps 1.4 shield. On the software side I'm running a version of Marlin which I've configured for my setup.

The extruder is a remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1764815
The smart controller holder is a remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:563515

If you are genuinely interested in building this printer yourself I'd be more than happy to provide you with all the information to do so. (Please write a comment) I do not recommend this printer to a beginner since it requires a lot of hacking and tweaking.

Since I've taken the pictures I've added a heated bed in order to print ABS parts and flat PLA parts more reliably. I also added a second Z axis stepper driver and changed the location to the sides of the printbed to prevent the printbed from sagging.

description.text:
Hello All! I had to hot glue the bearing into place, and the top to the middle piece, sorry about that. You'll also need to change the height of the desk clip to meet your needs, right now it's set for a 30 mm desk, i use paper for some padding.

This took a lot of tweaking to get put together how it needs to be, but i'm pretty happy with where it ended up.

Once everything is said and done it works pretty well for a cellphone stand. I was worried about it sliding all over the place so I have on that clips onto a desk, but I move in proportion to my desk so I wanted it to swivel. Best of all worlds!

Ok that's all i have to say about that.

Live long and prosper.

Oh also i used a monoprice mini so it'll print pretty easily for one. I would use support for the top cellphone holder though. Everything else doesn't require them.

author: Mylez_

description.text:
This is an simple device used to check if a cable is live or not. It is a quick way to find the right cable in a bundle when there is no connector to probe directly on. Just push the sharp metal probe through the isolation and watch if the LED lights up. It is mainly for car electronics so it's mainly for 12V.
Some soldering required and a small resistor around 300 Ohm and an LED.
The hand drawn sketches shows the basic how it works.

180111: Made longer for easier access to "hard to reach" cables.

title: Royal Game of Ur
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Royal Game of Ur one of the oldest examples of board gaming equipment found, although Senet boards found in Egyptian graves predate it as much as 900 years. The Ur-style Twenty Squares gameboard was also known in Egypt as Asseb, and has been found in Pharaoh Tutankhamen's tomb, among other places. Discovery of a tablet partially describing the gameplay has allowed the game to be played again after over 2000 years, although reconstructions of the detailed rules have differed widely.
When I made the Senet Game I thought it would be good to also make this game in a similar style. Board as a Lid and box to hold all the pieces.

This is a pulley and weight hanger assembly suitable for use in a physics classroom. Designed for use with SimpleSumo robots: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2574286

author: Rodjerhell

description.text:
I took them directly from: https://www.bcn3dtechnologies.com/es/sigma-downloads/

They are not my property.

This is the modified version of the prusa3d's mmu jig where you don't need as much metal component as the official one; cooling tube, brass screw insert for the pneumatic fittings.

All of these has 6mm diameter for the pneumatic fitting tube and does not require brass screw insert.

I included 3 versions:
v1. Filament pathway are similar to the original, you can use prusa3d's cooling tube as well
v2. Smoother filament pathway, no cooling tube required
v3. Square/diamond pathway

Oddly, I had problems with v1 and v2 where the filament won't able to go through the jig where it works with v3 which has diamond/square shaped pathway. There's a little chance that if you print the v1 and v2 or the original prusa3d's mmu design, the filament unable to go through the jig. This might be due to some filament sagged in there somewhere making the filament unable to go through smoothly.

Danger!!!

After printing the jig, try feeding the filament through and DO NOT LOOK directly through the output side of the jig will feeding it as it may poke your eyes to blindness if you're not careful.

This is especially for the jigs where the filament got stuck inside

Compatibility

This is compatible with my previous uploaded designs, and compatible with the original prusa3d's extruder designs as well. Links to the extruder mounts are as follows

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2558425
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2171406

For the hotends, I use this on my custom machine that uses cheap chinese e3d. and no need those pneumatic fitting fitted there.

For those who're using teflon liner in the heater block, the length are roughly around 55mm and make sure you tapper/chamfer the inner side of the teflon liner. The tappered/chamfered side has to sit on top which will be inside the jig. This should apply to e3d v6 lite as well

For those who're using stainless steel/metal type heatbreak, the teflon tube length are around 45mm (as prusa3d's spec) and top side, chamfer the inside of the short teflon tube.

This has been tested with prusa3d's slic3r and it is able to print well. Do note that any custom machine are not compatible with prusa3d slic3r version 1.37.1 and above as for the beginning of this version, they added priming code only for original prusa printers.

description.text:
A small pulley for rc yachts based around a Boca bearing.
I don't have the product number for the bearing as I bought it from our local RC helicopter shop. Using my calipers I get in ID of 3mm and OD of 6mm.

Printer:

Flex Mendel / OSC Flex

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100

Notes:

Designed for my 0.4mm nozzle 0.2mm layer height.

Single STL bits and a file I exported from Slic3r Prusa as a single file that opens up flat on the build plate.
Fusion360 solid bodies in case you want to tweak it. Shout if there's a different format that you need (as long as Fusion supports it)

I printed quite slowly, with a very cold extrusion temp in PLA. I did 4 of them per print to allow the parts to cool to avoid the detailed bits getting mushed around.

By design, pieces need to be gently tapped together with a hammer to keep things snug. This de-burrs them and creates a tight clip when doing the final assembly.

There is a small gap between the post that centres the bearing on the Spacer and Base to allow for any z calibration issues.

I used a drop of CA to hold the spacer/ base together - be careful not to get any on the wheel/bearing sections.

print_settings.Notes:: If you are planning on measuring liquids, i would recommend at least 3 shell layers.

description.text:
I need to make 2.5, 5, 10 and 15 tablespoon measurements regularly. Even the shortcuts to those measurements are tedious (e.g. 10T = 1/2C + 2T). I figured that my 3D printer and I ought to do something about that.

Those specific measurement sizes probably aren't very useful to anyone but me, but I have included the OpenSCAD file, so if you need another size and aren't afraid to use OpenSCAD, go for it. Instructions for creating a measuring cups in this style of your own size are in "How I Designed This" below.

In addition to being able to measure the intended volume accurately, a label has been added to the top of the handle to identify the measured amount. The label is also customizable in OpenSCAD.

There are also small lip cutouts to prevent dribbling down the side of the cup when you pour and finger hole cutouts in the handles to make them easier to grip.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

40%+

Notes:

For cups that are 10 tablespoons and larger, you may (if your printer behaves like mine) need active cooling for the lower 25% of the model - the part where the sphere is curved slightly up, but is somewhat flat.

I printed in PLA and had issues with the edges of the overhangs on the sphere curling up until I added active cooling. If you do not have an active cooling system and this is a problem for you, you should be able to have a desk fan blow on the model after the first 1mm has printed and until the overhang decreases enough that the print is smooth. I would also suggest adding a small brim for larger measuring cups.

If you are planning on measuring liquids, i would recommend at least 3 shell layers.

OpenSCAD and some math

If you want to make a measuring cup of your own size, you will need to know the radius of a sphere that holds the measured volume. You can find volume by typing into Google, for example, "volume of 8 tablespoons in mm" Then:

Step 1. Do the math
V = (4/3) pi r^3
118294mm = 4.1888 * r^3
28240.5462mm = r^3
30.45mm = r

Step 2. Change the inputs to makeCup
makeCup( 30.45, "8T" );

Step 3. Adjust the label offset
Set the textOffsetDivisor value. 2.5 will probably work (or be close)

Step 3a. Optionally set extraOffset in makeHandle below to make the handle closer to or further away from the main cup

Step 5. Render

Step 6. Export to STL

Step 7. Slice

Step 8. Print

I would also recommend testing by printing the 5 tablespoon cup to see if your printer needs an additional offset for the multiplicationFactor variable.

description.text:
Drop Spindles - Three sizes and OpenSCAD source.

Turkish style drop spindle for spinning yarn from fleece. Our smoothest results come from printing a pair of the wings together, then a stick on its own. You can also easily sand down any lumps or bumps if you want to do a batch lot of sticks. If a stick is broken, removing it and inserting a new one with an existing spinning project on it works out fine. For the best winding of the cob the pattern is under one arm, over two. The smallest size is great for novelty or spinning thread-thin. The largest spindle shown is the %125 and good for plying, but is much heavier than the %100

Thanks

To my expert spinning daughter Jenny Sutherland who helped refine the design with her deeper spinning knowledge.

Unlike some other spindles on thingiverse, this one is plain with no writing on it and has a very permissive creative commons license.

Printer:

Custom Design

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 - 0.2mm layers

Infill:

40% gives a good weight

Notes:
  • 0.2mm nozzle + 0.1 layers works well esp for the the smallest modesl.
  • 0.4mm nozzel and 0.2mm layers are fine for the larger models.

Mostly a question of how patient you are.

Can be printed in one go or as separate single pieces for extra smooth results.

Why we wanted it
A stock Ultimaker comes with a single extrusion head fixed to the X and Y axes. As we were experimenting with dual extrusion printing, modifying this design became increasingly inconvenient and time-consuming. To make developing the hardware-side of our multihead printing much easier, we decided to split the extruder head design into two indendent hardware parts. The 'frame' part is fixed to the X and Y axes and thus determines the head's location. To this frame, up to 4 'cassettes' can be attached. A cassette is flexible: it can hold a regular PLA extruder head, but can also contain a syringe, fan, equipment, etc. The cassettes are height-adjustable mounted to the frame. (1) Frame
Our first working prototype of the frame is cross-shaped plywood fortified with some regular M3 screws. The screws ensure that the frame is tightly fixed, so that no undesired vertical movement takes place. The bearings are not clearly visible, but are mounted inside. Relative to the stock extruder head, this frame is only 1 cm wider on each side (now 69x69 mm). The vertical slots on all insides of the cross are to connect a cassette unit, and allows to adjust each cassette height vertically. (2) Cassette
The extrusion part of the stock Ultimaker head has been moved to cassettes: small wooden parts that can be attached to the frame. Given the frame's cross-shape, up to four cassettes can be added to each frame. Our current extruder cassette prototypes are 27 x 31 x 60 mm (l x w x h) but can be customized at will. Two openings in the cassette allow it to be mounted to the frame with regular 12mm M3 screws at the desired height. As mentioned above, the cassettes can be replaced by anything you'd like to attach. We have successfully mounted two cassettes, each holding a PLA hot extrusion nozzle, and could make our first dual extrusion prints (later more on this). Currently, we're working on a 'fan' cassette to deliver (hot?) air to the hot nozzles and remove the need to mount a fan to the head itself; and we're looking into gel printing. More to come! (Developed at Protospace Utrecht with help from Douwe van der Veen)
With a lasercutter, things can't be much simpler than doing this:

description.header: 1. Take the .pdf or .svg file, and some 6mm and 4mm plywood;
2. Cut the pieces in the drawing. Materials are mentioned in the file;
3. For the wooden part that contains the white/blue ring extrusion tube: make a conical shape with a drill (like on the 'stock' wooden bottom extruder plate)
3. Dismantle your stock extruder head. Take the bearings out.
4. Put bearings into the cross-shaped frame. Reattach the axes to Ultimaker.
5. Use 10 mm M3 screws to tighten. We use 16mm M3 screws to connect the cassette to the frame.
6. Mount the extrusion tube in a similar fashion as with the stock Ultimaker.
description.text: Note: no aluminium plate needed in our experience. The 6 mm wood works well enough, and the cassettes are sturdy enough to resist bending.

description.text:
A giant spider I modelled up for a Halloween decoration. There is a hole in the thorax to let you put through a zip tie or string to mount the spider on a fence for decoration, or incorporate into a really scary costume!

The legs are posable, allowing you to position your spider exactly as you want! The tolerances are forgiving, letting you print a little bit smaller if you need, or as big as you want!

The spider was loosely based on the Orb Weaver known as eriophora transmarina, but in the Halloween spirit, I made the features all a bit more scary, even incorporating a hint of a haunted pumpkin face into the back of the abdomen.

Print, and have fun!

This is a Battery holder for 12 AAA, 8 AA and 4 9V Blocks.
There are 2 files,
The "Batteriehalter" has a 16mm width opening for the 9V blocks.
The "Batteriehalter g" has a 17.8mm width opening for the 9V blocks.
I did this because the width of the 9V blocks isn't every time the same, the 16mm was my first version but after a week i had a new 9V block from a different manufacturer and it didn't fit because it was 1mm thicker, so i made a second version with a wider opening.
So pay attention which size your 9v block have. Or print the bigger one to be sure it fits.

author: Silent_Bob

title: Motorized Cube gears with removable base

description.text:
Like everyone else here I'm sure, I love Emmett's cube gears (all his creations really. Did I say I was a fan!! ). The monogrammed ones have made their way into several of the Christmas and birthday presents I have given out. I have always wanted to take them to the next step though and motorize them like I have seen that others have done, but I didn't want to give up my ability to still play with them. So, I thought up a way to modify it to work both ways! Yep, you can motorize it and play with it by hand!!! I extended the pin for one of the big corner blocks and put a hex shape at the end. I made a hole through the corner block to accommodate the extended pin. I also made three parallel rounded indents into the three sides of the corner to provide a way to hold it in place. Then I took a geared motor that I got cheap on e-bay and made a case around it with a battery holder and a lid with three cylinders to fit into the slots in the cube. I added a driver to the motor to match up with the hex shape and let her rip. (there was actually a few iterations and moments of head scratching involved) To switch the power, I went with a simple solution of making a flexible tab in the battery lid that pushes the wire onto the top of the battery. Simple and elegant! Now I can freely play with the cube gears and have a nice stand to set it on that amazes everyone when I show them what happens when I press the button. Modifying an existing geared cube (5-6 version with new pins) to work with this is as simple as taking off one of the big corners and replacing it with the new pin and corner. Here's a of video of my son playing with it:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TWgoSRPvsrQ Update - I ordered a couple of standard geared motors (should get in a couple of weeks) that are more freely available than the salvaged ones I used. I will update this with a new base when I have tested it with the new motor.

You need the center piece, 7 regular pins, 4 small corners, 3 large corners, the power_cube_hex_pin and the power_cube_corner to make the geared cube. If you have an existing 5-6 cube gears (with the new pins) you can just replace the one corner. For an even more interesting one, use Emmett's "Three Cube Gears" customizer to make custom large corners with your own words on each of the three sides! next you need a motor to run it. I shared the tinkercad object (link below) so that you can modify it to work with whatever motor you have. The real keys to the base are the holder and driver. The rest can be modified to suit your needs. https://tinkercad.com/things/hXUquljhpEd-powercubegears/edit

comments.text: I think that the main reason it works so well is because I have the cube turning so freely. I use CRC Heavy Duty Silicone spray to lube my moving parts.  At first things barely move after I spray them, but a few hours later they move quite well and the next day after they have dried completely, it turns Very freely.

author: rboutrois

description.text:
This is an attempt to design a small, continuous-rotation servo powered two-wheel rover that can carry a Raspberry Pi. The idea was to modify two cheap 9g servos to provide continuous rotation output on the two main wheels, with an additional passive swiveling front wheel. The servos were modified by drilling out the output shaft enough so it no longer rotates the feedback potentiometer (set to the center position - to be on the safe side, I also added a drop of glue to the potentiometer).
I added grooves for rubber O-rings (found at the hardware store plumbing section) on the big wheels to add traction.
I have driven the rover around with a regular RC receiver, the Raspberry Pi has yet to be added.
There is an STL for the full assembly included - in order to print it, you should download the OpenSCAD source and export the individual sub-components separately (two big wheels, front wheel, base, front 'suspension'). I used two small ball bearings from a broken RC helicopter (5mm diameter, I believe) for the front wheel swiveling and rotating axis.

comments.text: Can you change the design to have the wheels and frame separate for easy printing? Thanks.
comments.author: TheFlyingFoam

comments.text:
I added the missing files. Truth be told, I never did much with the rover and would probably change a few things if I were to build another one. Attaching the wheels to a servo axle firmly is tricky (I ended up using hot glue, I think) - I would probably redesign the wheels to accept an existing servo horn via a 'pocket' rather than trying to bolt the wheel directly to the axle.
Also, the CG of the whole design is quite high with a relatively short and narrow wheelbase - it tips pretty easily...
Anyways, hopefully the files are useful to you.

title: '$' Money Box
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Money Boxes are a fun container designed primarily to store money with spaces specifically for notes, large coins and small coins.

You can also use 'Money Boxes' to store away all sorts of other small things including keys, memory cards, parts, nuts / bolts and much more...

'Money Boxes' are an easy 2 piece print with a base and cap. Two different depth bases are provided (approx. 36mm and 72mm internal) but the cap file is the same for both.

Printing each part in a different color to create an interesting and different / unique look.

This print needs good build plate adhesion, well sliced files and an accurate / precise machine are essential to achieve a great result with snug fitting parts (lid and base). The 72mm internal depth base in particular is a sizeable print that will takes several hours to print... but the end result is worth the time and filament. At standard scale the parts are approx. 100mm x 100mm (X/Y).

Please refer to the print settings and images for additional information... and post images of your Money Boxes for other members to see.

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my practical and fun designs.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator+

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard / 0.20mm

Infill:

PLA / 2 Shells / 10% infill or more

Notes:

Money Boxes are an easy two part print. Good build plate adhesion is required to ensure the parts are printed accurately so they fit together snuggly and almost seamlessly.

Raft is recommended to assist with build plate adhesion. Do not us automated support.

Just remove the Raft...

...once your raft has been removed just fill with money or other small things then put the lid on like any regular container.... this is just a unique / novel approach to storage.

title: M8 Circular Threading Die Guide (Die Ø 25mm)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Tapping exact vertically oriented threads on bolts isn't that easy. A die guide helps for outer threads. Needed some bolts with threads for my GTA 6000 Stand Feet and created this die guide for circular M8 guides with a 25mm diameter.

Please note that the precision of the guidance tube heavily depends on your printer's tolerances. I made a couple of test prints to get a tube that has as less play as possible. Though it worked for me using PLA I recommend using a more sturdy material like, e.g., ABS.

title: MK8 Mount Oneup Twoup Threeup Q3D

description.text:
Designed this for my 175mm Q3D ThreeUp. I had another uploaded but that one didnt drop the MK8 far enough for the x carriage to come to the bed., This one recesses it down, You'll see/ This holds the mk8 extruder and has a thicker back wall 8.5mm thick to space the MK8 far out enough to clear my X-Axis endstop. This one had thick white endstops with red button switches. I still had to grind down the fan guard so it cleared a mounting screw on the endstop. And offsets will need to bet set.

x4 bolt holes are spaced 28mm apart square and recessed
Made for 45mm x 8mm diameter bearing spaced 55mm apart
Printed at 0.4 layer resolution
Perimeter 40mm/s
Solid Layers 30mm/s
Bridging 30mm/s
Infill 35mm/s
Travel 160mm/s
Used ABS by inland came out great. You need an m3 screw and nut.
The bracket my buddy gave me with the printer that is the plate that connects the X-Axis 45mm long 8mm diameter rod bearings, had 28mm spaces between all four hole mounts. No matter which version i found on Thingiverse the holes were way too close together. So if you have the bigger backplate or whatever upgrade my buddy did. I believe its 55mm from center rod to center rod on my back plate.

More from 3D Printer Extruders

title: Mark VII Science Tricorder - Star Trek TNG

description.text:
This is a remix of the Mark VII Science Tricorder by @ vesperk38. This version has a few changes:
-New hinge type, with pins included.
-A few touch-ups to the sensors
-A flat variant with smooth surfaces instead of buttons. This variant is for those who prefer to use the printed graphics rather than paint.

Instructions:

-Print the base type you want and a flip.
-Print two of the hinge pins.
-Depending on your printer, you may need to sand the pins. The were a good fit on my MK2S but did require some force pushing them in.
-The included graphics can be printed on a color laser, cut and applied with double-sided tape.

Additional attributions:

-The hinges are adapted from "Small hinge by dlaguerre"
-The graphics and screen inlays (and more inlays) are from alexkalcher.de.

comments.text: These seem like some fantastic upgrades!!! my compliments.

author: neworbit

description.text:
To make this you need

  • 8mm linear rod bearing
  • x2 M3 35mm bolts
  • x2 M3 nuts
  • 3mm or 1/8th inch drill bit
  • Drill

This decrease the jostle on the side that doesnt have the belt on the Y-Axis. 1 does a great job but if you mirror the image I included 2 work incredibly great.

This seriously stabilizes the Y-axis and the bed.
I printed at

  • .4 layer
  • 35mm/sec
  • 135% flowrate
  • 200% default extrusion width
  • 262C/100C
  • ABS (Inland Clear)

Make sure to strip out the plastic m3 threads so its easy to tighten down the m3 nut. Its hard keeping a tool on that small nut but once you tighten it, its awesome.

title: Razor holder for 22mm or 25mm shower pole

description.text:
A razor holder for the shower. Fits to a 22mm or 25mm diameter upright shower head pole.
The holder will accommodate three razors, or similar items.

Revisions / Updates:
24/12/2017 - Increase the strength of the shower pole clip, thickening the band slightly. Added the alternative clip, to fit a 25mm diameter shower pole.

2/1/2018 - Thickened the material at the point where the inner clip joins the body of the shower rail loop, to increase strength.

26/2/2018 - Uploaded new version of the 25mm pole mount, in response to feedback that errors were produced. Found a missing facet in the curved section which didn't cause me any issues, but may have affected others. Hopefully this will be better.

Printer:

Geeetech G2S

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

FIne adjustment

Depending on your printer, you may need to tweak the surfaces of the pole mount with a file, if it's a very tight fit.

Design notes

Scanned the original shower accessory tray for the basic shape, and then tweaked from there. Designed in SketchUp.

description.text: These are corrected rails for MagHak, I printed about 5 of original, and each of them had problem at the corner parts of rails, they did not hold, and fell during printing causing more problems. These rails corrected that error.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

how to video This is a fun, easy print that take up just a tiny amount of filament. One of the cool features of a soft flexible like NinjaFlex (SH=85A) is that it sticks really well to windows and mirrors when printed at 1mm to 3mm thickness. It's important that your print surface and the windows you stick the decals on are clean ;) to insure smooth against smooth. Just wet with water and stick. I have some up in my office that have been there for over a year. If you don't have any flexible filament you can buy some magnets at a craft store and turn these into refrigerator magnets. I started with images downloaded from pixabay from their free section and edited them for printing.

I create these designs to encourage people to try out flexible filaments or get some new interesting colors of flexibles. For info on purchasing samples of several brands of flexible filament see flexyfilament.com

Check out Flower, Butterfly and Bee Decals for Flexible Filament and the rest of my decal collection

Attempt at making a small, printable quadcopter frame. The center plate and arms are printed separately so they can be replaced as needed.
The assembly is held together by nylon bolts that go through pockets in the base which hold the individual arms. The bolts I chose were long enough to also double as landing gear legs.
In order to stiffen up the arms I added braces from the bolts to the center of the four arms, to be attached there with zip-ties.
The hole pattern on the arms fits the motor mounts included with HobbyKing 18-11 2000kv Micro Brushless Outrunners.
The holes on the base plate are spaced to mount a 2" x 2" perf board on which my (home brew) electronics are based. The electronics and motors are currently still mounted on a different frame, I have to yet fully assemble and test this frame.
Indiviual STLs for the major components are provided.
EDIT: Added photo of the completed setup - cable management may require some work.

title: HP P3005 Thrust Stopper p/n RC2-0657-000
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The HP P3005 laserjet printer is a workhorse. After many pages it may become necessary to replace the fuser drive gears, about a $15 fix. One of the gears is retained by a little clip HP calls the "thrust stopper." The gear replacement instructions warn you not to drop the clip inside the printer...

Not wanting to spend $10 for a tiny piece of plastic nor wait a month for shipping from China, I designed a replacement. This part has many inscrutable features. What do they do? Are they all necessary? Who knows? But not one to second-guess HP engineers I attempted to faithfully reproduce every detail of the clip.

I used PLA through a 0.2mm nozzle running at 2400mm/min and it printed really well. Works just like the original.

title: Fast Temperature Tower
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The Tacblades Temperature Tower
Can be used for any temperature range you like in Simplify3d or Cura
Very fast and easy to print, has slotted section to test adhesion for the temperature above it.
The reason it does not have temperature values on the side is that is prints much faster this way uses less filament and can be configured to any temperature you like for all filament types.

Included is a CR10 gcode file from 190 - 225
An S3d Factory File
An S3d Profile for PLA with the temperatures set.
A gcode file ready for PLA on the CR10

It has 8 sections
Best printed at 0.2mm layer height with a 0.4mm nozzle.
All section are 10mm high or 50 layers so set the temp changes at this point which is the layer below the cutouts.

To print using Simplify3d just set temperature processes every 50 layers, see image.

In Cura 2.4 use Extensions->Post Processing->Modify G-Code
then click Add Script and select TweakAtZ
Select Layer No. (from 1 and every 50) Keep Value and set extruder temp see image.

Then just slice and print see tips below for slicing.

Printer:

Creality CR-10s

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Set to one outer shell layer, 2 top layers and 2 bottom layers
Does not need vase mode.
Walls will be one nozzle width thick.
No Brim
Make sure in Cura you have print thin walls selected in the shells section might be hidden.

Testing

You can see surfaces flat or curves and small bridging,
and use the flat surfaces or the cut outs to break apart to test the adhesion strength.

description.text: hi , this is a landing gear for my conversion to a 450 zmr drone . It is made with 8mm carbon rod

This iPad holder is designed to be placed on the headrest of the two front seats in a car, for the passengers on the backseat to enjoy a movie. I have made a derivative so it is possible to place the iPad on just a single frontseat - but this original version fits my needs for the coming holiday. Feel free to derive or suggest improvements :)

Print the parts on your 3d-printer. Try to follow how I positioned the parts to ensure best rupture strength for the individual parts. Use a power drill to make the hole go through in part B. Then get the following from your hardware store: 2x64cm 10mm Aluminum Tube (Might be shorter if you want to try a derived design with only one carseat) 5 pcs M4 30mm (or preferred 25mm) bolts
5 pcs M4 nuts
2 pcs M8 40mm bolts
2 pcs M8 nuts Follow the images if you are unsure how to assemble the kit.

comments.author: PurpleTentacle

comments.text: Thank you! Colors are easy. First I base coat with black primer spray. Then I turn to interior house paint, 500 ml acrylic paint. I start with a dark brown with a very slight green. Cover it with that. Then a gradual drybrush with a gray/yellow color. Drybrush it lightly many times to build it up. The doors and details where painted a pale pink, then washed with a darker color, the drybrushed with the first pink again.

title: Spool Bracket for Prusa i3 style printer

description.text:
This is a spool holder for my Prusa i3 style printer (novalabs.org Build Group IX)

There are a lot of nice designs out there already, but I wanted something basic that would print fast. It was also an excuse to try out Fusion360.

Thanks for looking, enjoy!
Bob M

Here's How I Designed It
  1. Measure and sketch the critical sizes where the spool holder would snap on the frame
  2. Add a triangular shaped arm, dimension it so it would fit a typical spool
  3. Add some trusses. I did this intuitively. Its been a while since I took ESM2000 at Va Tech as an EE major, so these are strictly TLAR (that looks about right).
  4. Now the fun part, add some some offset to the truss members for thickness and extrude.
  5. Then had some more fun with the fillets tool
  6. I added a small foot hopefully to reduce wobble.
  7. Export STL, brought into Slic3r, and reoriented so Z-axis is up
  8. Slice and print
